It is located in Piura region, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo.

Juana María has an establishment in her home where she sells meals, beer, snacks and 'chicha de jora' (a traditional Peruvian, corn-based drink).  Juana María prepares the food in her home and sells it on weekends.  Owing to the good taste of her meals and the good service that she provides, there is a stable demand for her business.  She uses the profits that she makes from this activity to get her family ahead financially.

Juana María would like to acquire more supplies to expand her business and satisfy the demand that she has right now.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa that will help her achieve her goal.  Juana María is an active and hard-working woman.  Her greatest wish is to continue growing as a businesswoman until she is able to set up her own restaurant.

loans.use: To acquire more supplies so that she can expand her business and satisfy the demand that she has right now

loans.name: Rosa Delia

texts.es:
Rosa tiene 38 años de edad, es divorciada y reside junto a sus tres hijos en uno de los caseríos que conforman el distrito agrícola de Tambogrande, una zona de clima semitropical que produce principalmente frutas como mango, maracuyá y limón. Pertenece a la región Piura y se encuentra ubicado a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la comercialización de prendas de vestir para todo público. Ella ofrece su mercadería en base a pedidos y también cuenta con un stock permanente en su domicilio. Usualmente ofrece su mercadería a los vecinos de la zona, aunque también suele recorrer los caserío aledaños en busca de más clientes. Esta actividad es la única que le permite hacerse cargo del mantenimiento de sus menores hijos, por lo que siempre trata de mantenerlo del mejor modo posible.

Rosa desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más mercadería con prendas de vestir de temporada de verano, con esa inversión ella pretende aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ingresos con los cuales pueda sacar adelante a sus menores hijos. Para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Rosa is 38 years old.  She is divorced and lives with her three children in one of the villages that make up the agricultural district of Tambogrande.  This is an area with a semi-tropical climate that mainly produces fruit such as mangos, passion fruit and lemons.  It is located in Piura region, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of Lambayeque region.

Rosa sells clothes to the general public.  She takes orders for her merchandise and also has a fixed stock in her home.  She usually offers her merchandise to her neighbors, though she also travels to neighboring villages in search of more customers.  This is the only business activity Rosa carries out to support her dependent children so she always does her best to maintain her business as well as possible.

Rosa would like to expand her business, buying more merchandise: clothes for the summer season.  She is making this investment to increase her sales and make more profits which she can use to get her children ahead in life.  In order to achieve her goal, she is requesting a loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise: summer clothes

loans.name: Alberto

texts.es:
Alberto tiene 54 años de edad, es casado y reside junto a su esposa y a sus tres hijos en uno de los caseríos que conforman el distrito agrícola de Tambogrande, la zona cuenta con un clima semitropical que produce principalmente frutas como el mango, limón y maracuyá. Pertenece a la región Piura y se encuentra ubicada a más de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a trabajar en la crianza y venta de ganado vacuno y ovino. El cría ovejas y vacas en unos corrales situados cerca a su domicilio. Alberto vende las ovejas a sus vecinos y a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona en donde reside. Adicionalmente ofrece en venta la leche que producen sus vacas. Los ingresos que el percibe de estas actividades le sirven para sacar adelante la economía de su familia.

Alberto desea adquirir alimentos para mejorar la crianza de sus animales y poder percibir mayores ganancias que le permitan mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.
texts.en:
Alberto is 54 years old, married and lives with his wife and three children in one of the villages that make up the agricultural district of Tambogrande.  The area has a semi-tropical climate and mainly produces fruit such as mangos, lemons and passion fruit.  It is located in Piura region, more than one hour from the city of Chiclayo, capital of Lambayeque region.

Alberto raises and sells cattle and sheep.  He raises his sheep and cows in some pens located behind his home.  Alberto sells the sheep to his neighbors and the traders who usually visit the area where he lives.  He also sells the milk that his cows produce.  The profits that Alberto makes from this business help him to get his family ahead financially.  

Alberto would like to acquire animal feed so that he can improve his animal raising business and make more profits that will allow him to improve his family's quality of life.  For this reason, he is requesting a loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa that will help him achieve his goal.

loans.use: To acquire animal feed to improve his animal raising business

loans.name: Ballivian Group

texts.es:
El Banco D. emprendimiento "Ballivian" esta en su segundo ciclo ha tenido un buen desempeño en su primer ciclo ha cumplido con el pago D. sus cuotas con mucha responsabilidad las socias D. dicho banco son comerciantes minoristas D. venta D. comida y servicios, la presidenta es la Sr. María que se dedica a la venta D. comida es una persona muy trabajadora se levanta desD. muy tempranas horas D. la mañana para preparar sus deliciosos platos y después lo va a vender en su puesto D. venta donD. le va muy bien ya que tiene mucha clientela por el buen sazón D. sus platillos, con el dinero del  crédito comprara insumos como aceite, papa, fideo, por mayor para la elaboración D. sus platillos, esta agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
Las socias sacaron el crédito para aumentar su capital para sus actividades y se fueron muy satisfechos con el crédito
texts.en: The Ballivian bank is in its second cycle and had a good performance in its first cycle, paying its quotas with great responsibility. The members of this bank are merchants who sell food and proviD. services. The president is Maria, who sells food. She is a very hard-working woman who gets up very early in the morning to prepare her delicious dishes, and after she goes to her sales stall. It is going very well and she has many customers because of the good flavour of her dishes. With the money from this loan she will purchase wholesale inputs such as oil, potatoes, and pasta for making her dishes. She is grateful to the institution for the support offered. The members have taken out this loan to increase their capital for their businesses and have been very satisfied with the loan.

loans.use: the purchase of inputs

loans.name: Yegana

texts.ru:
Yegana M. 37 let. Ona yavlyayetsya IDP personom , ona pereselenec iz Kalbadjar regiona i seychas projivayet v Absheron regione so svoyey semyoy. Ona ne zamujem i ne imeyet detey. 

Yegana uje 8 let kak rabotayet uchitelnicey. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit knigi i testi dlya svoix uchenikov.
texts.en:
Yegana M. is 37 years old. She is an Internally Displaced Person from the Kalbadjar Region, now living in the Absheron Region with her relatives. She is single, without children. 

Yegana has been working as a school teacher for eight years. At present she needs 2,000 AZN in order to buy books and tests for her students.

loans.use: Purchasing books and tests for her students

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.ru:
Gulnara B. 41 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet odnu dochku kotoraya uchistya v kolledje. Ona jivet v Absheron regione  vmeste so svoim mujem i dochkoy. 

Gulnara uje 9 let kak rabotayet parexmaxerom v s voyom solone. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit nujnuyu elektro-texniku  dlya svoyey raboti, tak kak yeyo elektro -texniks uje staroye i mnoqiye isportilis.
texts.en:
Gulnara B. is 41 years old. She is married and has a daugther, who is a college student. She lives in the Absheron Region with her husband and daughter.

For nine years already, Gulnara has been working as a hairdresser in her own salon. At present she needs 2000 AZN to buy the necessary electrical appliances for her work, since her appliances are old and many don’t work properly.

loans.use: Buying the necessary electrical appliances for her work

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.ru:
Huseyn A. 29 let. On ne jenat i ne imeyet detey. On projivayet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoimi roditelyami. 

Seychas Huseyn nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit  testi i knigi dlya svoix uchenikov kotoriye sobirayustay postupat v universiteti, tak kak eti testi stoyat dorogo ne kajdiy uchnik imeyet vozmojnosti pokupat ix. Huseyn uje 2 qoda kak rabotayet uchitelem.
texts.en:
Huseyn A. is 29 years old. He is single, without children. He lives in the Absheron Region together with his parents.

At present Huseyn needs 2000 AZN in order to buy tests and books for his students who plan to apply to college, because these tests are expensive, and not all students can afford them. Huseyn has been working as a schoolteacher for two years.

loans.use: Purchasing tests and books for his students

loans.name: Tunzala

texts.ru:
Tunzala S. 40 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 2 detey. Tunzala  jivet v qorode Baku vmeste so svoim mujom i detmi, kotoriye uchatsya v kolledje.

Tunzala uje 7 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji produktov. Ranshe Tunzala  prodovala korm dlya jivotnix ,tak je moyushiye sredstva i t.d a seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit uje pishiviye produkti dlya prodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en:
Tunzala S. is forty years old.  She is married and has two children.  Tunzala lives in the city of Baku with her children, who study in college, and with her husband.

Tunzala has been selling foodstuffs for seven years.  Before that, Tunzala sold pet food, cleaning supplies, and other things.  Now, she needs 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs for sale and to expand her business.

loans.use: Buying goods for resale

loans.name: Shakhin

texts.ru:
Shakhin Z. 28 let. On jenat no poka ne imeyet detey. Shakhin jivet v qorode Baku so svoyey jenoy. Shakhin uje 5 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom , v qruzavoy mashine vodit qruz. 

Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya svoyey qruzovoy mashini, tak kak yeqo mashina isportilas i on ne mojet vodit qruzi.
texts.en:
Shakhin Z. is 28 years old.  He is married, but as of yet still does not have children.  Shakhin lives in the city of Baku with his wife.  Shakhin has been working as a truck driver hauling freight for five years.

Now he needs 2000 AZN to buy parts for his truck.  His truck broke down and he currently cannot haul freight.

loans.use: Buying parts for a truck

loans.name: Sevda

texts.ru:
Sevda B. 47 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 5 detey, 3 iz kotorix uchatsya v kolledje a dva ix kotorix uchatsya v shkole. Sevda jivet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoim mujem i detmi. 

Sevda uje 12 let kak rabotayet uchitelniccey. Seychas ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi rasshirit pomesheniye qde ona zanimayetsya so svoimi uchenikami tak kak ix stanovitsya bolshe i ona zanimayetsya qruppami.
texts.en:
Sevda B. is 47 years old.  She is married and has five children.  Three of her children go to college while the other two go to school.  Sevda lives in the Absheron region with her husband and children.

Sevda has been a teacher for twelve years.  She needs 2000 AZN to expand her classroom since the students she teaches as a group are growing up.

loans.use: To expand her classroom

loans.name: Shasta Daisy Group

texts.en:
Nancy R. is from the village of Sepac Sapang Dalaga Mis. Occ. She is 37 years old. Nancy is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shasta Daisy.

Nancy is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Nancy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as canned goods, noodles, milk, sugar, spices, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Nancy has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nancy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nancy is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Nancy from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to resell and acquire working capital.

loans.name: Lucel's Group

texts.en:
Lucel P. is from the village of Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Lucel is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tundan2.

Lucel is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a tailoring business, providing new clothing services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $46 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lucel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Lucel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old. Evelyn is widowed and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products such as soft drinks, canned goods, noodles like pancit, behon and meki, spices, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Evelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora B. is from the village of Seti, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Flora is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she raises goats to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $20 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Flora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. 

Flora is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 5th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

texts.en:

To make a living, Anna Lisa owns & operates a business providing water refilling services to the local community members. Anna Lisa has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Anna Lisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anna Lisa from GDMPC. loans.name: Madelyn's Group

texts.en:
Madelyn Y. is from the village of Looc Libertad Sapang Dalaga Mis. Occ. She is 28 years old. Madelyn is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Luxurious.

Madelyn is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Madelyn owns & operates a business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Madelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Madelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Ikhbayar

texts.en: Ikhbayar is 30 years old, married, and the father of two children. He lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His family lives together in a small wooden house. His wife Urangua works as a warehouse keeper at a construction company. His older son goes to a local secondary school, while his younger son stays at home. Ikhbayar has been operating a taxi service in the city for the last three years. He also works for a construction company as a plumber on a part-time basis. In the mornings, he takes his wife to work and his son to school. He is a very hard-working person who is providing a good education for his children. This is his third Kiva loan through Credit Mongol. He has used his previous loans appropriately, paying them back in full on time. This time he is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to complete improvements to his house.

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Junifer

texts.en:
Junifer A. is from the village of Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 24 years old. Junifer is single. To make a living, Junifer works in someone else's business operating jeepney transport services. Junifer has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Junifer joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Junifer is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Junifer from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Odelio's Group

texts.en:
Odelio A. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 42 years old. Odelio is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Odelio is single. To make a living, Odelio owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Odelio has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Odelio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Odelio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Odelio is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Odelio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Zahidahan's Group

texts.en:
Zahidahan U., 37, is the leader of this group.  She is married and brings up a daughter and two sons. Her husband earns money by repairing household appliances and the children are at school. Zahidahan herself is engaged in farming. She started this activity in 1996, when the collective farms broke up. The family was given a piece of land for farming. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase mineral fertilizers and to hire labor for plowing the land. In the future, she wants to provide a good education for her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Rosalie's Group

texts.en:
Rosalie D. is from the village of San Andres. She is 44 years old. Rosalie is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalie D.'s Group.

Rosalie is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns & operates a general store, selling food products in the local community. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosalie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Rosalie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:

To make a living, Dominador owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Dominador has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Dominador joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dominador is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase his crop yield. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Dominador from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Munkherdene

texts.en: Munkherdene is 24 years old, married, and has one son. His family lives together in a wooden house on their plot of land in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife Nyamdulam, who is also 24 years old, is studying to become a lawyer at a state university. Their parents take care of their son in Bayankhongor province. Munkherdene used to work at an auto repair shop as a manager. In 2009, he began operating his own business replacing and fixing car windshields. Munkherdene is planning to expand his business in the future. He is requesting 2,800,000 MNT loan to increase his working capital.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
46-year-old Bernard M. is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya. He has been in the farming business for 10 years and employs two farmhands. His farm produces coffee and horticultural products, which he sells through a local cooperative society. Farming is his main source of income.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 53,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He hopes that his income, through the sale of milk and this loan, will help improve the livelihood of his family.  His primary challenges are lack of reliable vet doctors and artificial insemination services. He hopes that in the future, he will be able to produce over 50 liters of milk daily.

Bernard is married with three children who all attend school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya where she has been farming for 18 years. She employs one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces milk, maize and beans, which she sells to the local market. She also earns income from her small-scale business. 

Agnes is 48 years old and married with four children. Two of the children are adults and two attend school.

She has requested this loan of 53,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase an insured cow and construct a dairy unit. She says that this loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase her income through the sale of milk.  In future, she hopes to construct a good zero grazing unit that will enable her to increase the number of dairy cows from one to five.

loans.use: To purchase an insured cow and construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mr. Soeun S. (shown in the photo) is 32 years old and his wife, Mrs. Somnang Poch, is 31 years old. They have been married since 1996 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Soeun and his wife are farmers. They grow rice and lotus on their farmland in the village. Besides farming, Soeun is a fisherman as well. He is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Thai

texts.en:
Mr. Thai H. (shown in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Sakhorn Sbaung, live along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple is old, but they are still strong enough to work. 

Mr.Thai H. and his wife are rice and lotus farmers. Farming is the main business to support their standard of living. They hope to continue the business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their farm. Therefore, Thai is applying for another loan in the amount of $500.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his farm.

loans.name: Sam-Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-aun S. (shown in the photo) is 35 years old and her husband, Mr. Borom Pil, is 36 years old. They have been married since 1996 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of them are in school. The family lives along national road number six about 10 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sam-aun sells steamed corn. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting and to buy construction materials for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and to buy construction materials for her husband.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 42 years old and married with three school-aged children who all attend school. He is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where he has been farming for 20 years and employs five farmhands. His mixed farm produces coffee, horticultural products and milk which he sells to the local market and through Kenya Co-operative Creameries. He depends solely on the income from his farming activities to cater for his family's basic needs.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve his family's livelihood. He faces the challenge of a lack of veterinary services. He hopes to acquire five more high-yielding dairy cows in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Sal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sal H. (pictured above), 33 years old, and her husband, Mr. Savon Leng, also 33 years old, have been married since 1998 and have three children - two sons and one daughter. They live in a small village along National Road Number Three about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Mr. Savon Leng sells fruit in the local market.  
 
Mrs. Sal H. stays at home and does housework. The main source of income is from her husband’s business. She is requesting her first loan of US$1,000 to purchase neighboring land to expand her property.

loans.use: To purchase neighboring land to expand her property

loans.name: Shaimkan's Group

texts.en:
Kyrgyz and Russian markets are interdependent. Russia imports fresh vegetables, fruits and dried fruits from Kyrgyzstan, which in turn is dependent on Russian flour and grains. So far the exchange has been successful and both sides are hoping for a bright future of goods exchange. 

Shaimkan A., 52, is a treasurer of this group. It’s been 19 years since she and her husband began exporting fresh vegetables and fruits to Russian markets. They have raised two sons and a daughter, who have chosen different professions in life. Their daughter became a professional cook, one of their sons chose electrical maintenance, the other became a musician. 

After she was widowed, Shaimkan decided to stop her involvement in international trade and she started working in a local food market. She invested 20,000 soms for a business start-up. Now she earns 17,000 soms in monthly profit and puts this back into goods circulation. Shaimkan joined this group for a loan that would bring changes to her life. She would like to diversify the goods in her shop, and spend the proceeds on purchasing a new house. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where she has been farming for 16 years. She employs 2-4 casual laborers daily. Her main products are maize, milk, beans and eggs which she sells locally. She also runs a small business in the same location.

She has requested this loan of 50,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to improve her poultry project. The income from the sale of eggs will help improve her family's livelihood. She is currently rearing 30 layers but hopes to increase to over 2000 layers in future.

Winnie is 36 years old and married with five children who are between the ages of three and 16. Three of the children attend school.

loans.use: To improve her poultry project

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph has a mixed farm in Murang'a town, central Kenya, that produces coffee, tea and milk which he sells through Kenya Co-operative Creameries and Kenya Tea Development Authority. He occasionally employs three casual laborers. Farming is his only source of income.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve  his family's livelihood. In future, he hopes to increase the number of his dairy cows from the current one to five high-yielding dairy cows.

Joseph is 37 years old and married with one child aged seven who attends school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya. She has been farming for 13 years and employs one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces maize, beans and eggs, which she sells to the local market.

She has requested this loan of 50,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry farming. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of her family. Her biggest challenge in farming has been diseases, which affects her production. She currently has 12 layers and intends to improve in the future by acquiring at least 3,000 layers.

Lucy is 32 years old and married with three school-aged children who all attend school.

loans.use: To expand her poultry farming.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 46 years old and married with four children who are between the ages of 1 and 15. Three of the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya where he has been farming for 30 years. He employs one farmhand. His farm produces coffee and milk, which he sells to the local market and through Kenya Co-operative Creameries, respectively. He is also employed.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will go towards the education of his children. In five years' time, he hopes that he will be able to produce more than 50 litres of milk daily.

He is happy for the development projects that Juhudi is giving to the small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew has a mixed farm in the town of Murang'a in central Kenya that produces coffee and milk. He has been in the farming business for the last 10 years and employs one farmhand. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to provide the basic needs of his family.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family. In the future, he would like to acquire at least three dairy cows, which will improve his milk production. He faces the challenge of lack of artificial insemination services.

Mathew is 37 years old and married with one child, age 4, who attends school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Malikahon's Group

texts.en:
Malikahon S., 50, is the treasurer of this group. She is married to a barman. She has raised two sons. Both sons are working in Russia in a furniture factory. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Malikahon sells convenience goods on the market. In this way, she earns 8,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to expand her business and open one more trade place.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Edith Amondi

texts.en:
Edith Amondi N. is 24 years old and resides at Kopere in Kapsabet town. She is a single lady and has one child who she supports. Her child is one year old. For the past two years, Edith has operated a salon in Kopere trading centre. Her monthly profits from the business are 8,500 KES. 

She has borrrowed a loan of 40,000 KES, which she intends to use to purchase braids and hair driers for her business. The anticipated profits will be saved for her child's future education. This is Edith's third loan from KADET LTD. Her previous loan of 20,000 KES was paid back successfully. In the future, she hopes to move her business from a rural area to the city. She also hopes to open a supermarket and educate her child.

loans.use: To purchase braids and hair driers

loans.name: Karamathon's Group

texts.en:
Karamathon S. is the leader of this group. She is 65 and married. Her husband is retired and receives a monthly pension of 2,500 soms. Together they raised three sons and a daughter. The sons are working in construction and the daughter is in Russia. Karamathon and her husband are engaged in livestock breeding.  By reselling the livestock animals after fattening, they earn 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, the family wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future, Karamathon wants to purchase a piece of land and start building a house for her older son.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Aurenila Domingo's Group

texts.en:
Aurenila D., aged 44, is from the village of Pulay, Luna, Isabela. She is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Aurenila is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Aurenila owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Aurenila has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP monthly.

In 2007, Aurenila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Aurenila is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the sixth loan that Aurenila has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Sophie has a retail shop business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Sophie has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar and soap. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Sophie hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to become an accountant. Sophie is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her to protect herself in a positive way.

loans.use: To purchase sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Rady

texts.en:
Mrs. Rady S. (in the photo), 46 years old, and her husband, Mr. Vannak Monh, 47 years old, live in a village along National Road Number Two about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1984 and have seven children - three sons and four daughters. One is married, another one is a garment factory worker and five attend school.

Rady is hired by manufacturers in her village to recycle. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to dig a well for family use, to fill up the land of her house's foundation and to purchase a motorbike for her daughter to get to work.

loans.use: To dig a well for family use, to fill up the land of her house's foundation and to purchase a motorbike for her daughter to get to work

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Winnie has a retail shop business, which she has run for four years. She also sells charcoal.
To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Winnie hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. Winnie is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her an employment skill.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man M. (pictured here) and his wife have been married since 1980 and have five children - three sons and two daughters. Two are married and live outside the family home and the other three attend school. 

Man is a fisherman. His wife sells the fish that her husband catches in the village. He is applying for his third loan of $450 to purchase a new boat motor because the one he currently has is old and does not work well.

loans.use: To purchase a new boat motor

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Stella has a poultry business, which she has run for one year. She also has a retail shop.
To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase chicken feed and sugar. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Stella hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Stella hopes to become a nurse. Stella is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games.

loans.use: To purchase sugar for resale and chicken feed for her poultry business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase seed potatoes

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Margret has a business selling shoes, which she has run for four years. She also sells charcoal.
To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal and shoes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further. Margret is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future and taught her new games.

loans.use: To purchase shoes and charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastula N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are currently in school. Mastula has a business selling food, which she has run for four years. She also sells vegetables.
To help expand her business, Mastula has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Mastula hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Mastula is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To purchase more food for resale

loans.name: Phat

texts.en:
Mrs. Phat C. (pictured above), 35 years old, and her husband, Mr. Mao Rin, 36 years old, live in a small village along National Road Number Three about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have three children - two daughters and one son. 

Phat has been selling noodles (kuyteav or ka tieu) in her village for almost 10 years. Kuyteav is the sound of the Khmer word for these noodles eaten with soup. Her husband assists his wife in the business. She is requesting her first loan of US$300 to buy a new motorcycle for commuting  to replace the old one because it breaks down and uses more gasoline.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Rashidah

texts.en:
Rashidah N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. Rashidah has a dairy business, which she has run for one year.
To help expand her business, Rashidah has requested a loan of 100,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more milk. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rashidah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to sell charcoal. Rashidah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To purchase more milk for resale

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma B. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 58 years old. Norma is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Bolormaa is a 34-year-old married woman who lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent on her sister’s plot of land, which is near her business place. They don’t have any kids yet. Bolormaa operates a grocery store, selling items like meat and vegetables. She has been running this business for over three years and has a loyal customer base. Her husband helps her in the business and this is the only income for the family. She is planning to purchase her own plot of land and a wooden house with her savings. 

Bolormaa is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase cheaper meat and vegetables to sell for a profit.

loans.use: to purchase cheaper meat and vegetables to sell for a profit.

loans.name: Pousary

texts.en:
Mr. Pousary L. and his wife, Mrs. Asimas Mat, have been married since 1991 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. The family lives about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Pousary is a fisherman and sells the fish that he catches to a middleman who comes to buy them at his house. His wife assists her husband in the business. Pousary requested a loan of $500 to purchase a boat motor and fishing supplies for his business. 

Photo: Pousary with his wife and young son

loans.use: To purchase a boat motor and supplies for his fishing business.

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is a dairy farmer in Murang'a town, central Kenya, where he has been farming for five years. He sells his milk through Kenya Co-operative Creameries. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to take care of the needs of his family.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the increased income from the sale of milk will help in the education of his children. In the future, he would like to improve his dairy farming and be able to produce at least 50 liters of milk daily.

Cyrus is 29 years old and married with two children, ages 4 and 7.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Ruth has a business selling clothes, which she has run for one year.
To help expand her business, Ruth has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Ruth hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a house. Ruth is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Dany

texts.en:
Mrs. Dany K. (shown in the photo) is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Chantha Kem, is 38 years old. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1997 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two attend school and the other one is still young.  

Dany sells clothes. Her husband is a construction worker. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Christine has a business selling spare parts, which she has run for five years.
To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase spare parts. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Christine hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to get a good job. Christine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by showing her how to interact with people.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for resale

loans.name: Sopheak

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheak L. (pictured here) is 23 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Sokchea Sorm is 25 years old. They have been married since 2009 and have no children yet. They live with his parents and brothers and sisters along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sopheak is a motorcycle taxi driver. His wife is a garment factory worker. He hopes to change his business from motorcycle taxi to Tuk Tuk (a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi), because it could carry more goods and people than a motorcycle taxi. 

He asked for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a Tuk Tuk.

loans.use: To purchase a three-wheeled motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a farmer in Murang'a town in central Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for the past twenty years and employs one farmhand. His mixed farm produces milk and coffee which he sells locally. He also runs a small business in the same region.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will help improve the livelihood of his family. He plans to improve his dairy farming in the future by acquiring more dairy cows that will increase his income.

Joseph is 56 years old and married with four children who are all adults.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Wilma's Group

texts.en:
Wilma A. is from the village of Rizal West in San Isidro. She is 50 years old. Wilma is the group leader of a fourteen-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Wilma is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she manages a direct selling business, selling cosmetics and apparel products. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $69 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Wilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pisey

texts.en:
Mrs. Pisey S. (shown in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Chanthorn Phon, live on an island in the Mekong River roughly 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2003. Mr. Chanthorn has a full time job in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Pisey S. is a silk weaver. Besides selling her own silk products, she buys from other weavers in her village and resells to a middleman. She asked for another loan of $1,200 to continue her business by purchasing silk materials (raw silk) and buying silk fabric for resale.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her silk weaving business and to buy additional silk products for resale.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is 19 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. Justine has a dry-cleaning business, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase polythene jackets for keeping the clothes clean. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Justine hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Justine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to work.

loans.use: To purchase polythene jackets to protect cleaned items of clothing

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. Jenifer has a motorcycle(motor bike for transporting people) business, which she has run for three years. She also has a second business in selling clothes.

To help expand her business, Jenifer has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase motorcycle machines and clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jenifer hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to own a retail shop. Jenifer is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by assisting her in improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle machines and clothes

loans.name: Gerelmaa

texts.en:
Gerelmaa is 29 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her eldest two children attend a local secondary school and the youngest son stays at home.  She rents a stall at the market where she sells fruits and vegetables. She has been running this business since 2005. She has used her earnings to provide for her children and to pay their living expenses. 

Her husband Altanshagai, 27 years old, helps her business with his microbus by transporting her products to the market. In the future she is planning to increase her working capital and to give her children a good education and morals. 

She is applying for a loan for 900,000 MNT to purchase fruits and vegetables at wholesale prices to resell to her many customers.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira K. is the leader of this group.  She is 37 years old and married. Her husband works in Russia. Gulmira herself takes care of four children: three daughters and a son. All the children study at school. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Gulmira breeds livestock and then resells at a higher price after fattening them. In this way she earns about $65 per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future Gulmira wants to provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en:
Hajara N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child.  None of her children is currently in school.  Hajara has a business of a salon, which she has had for 3 years.  She also has a second business of a drug shop. 

To help expand her business, Hajara has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase braids for her salon.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hajara hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Hajara hopes to become a nurse.        Hajara is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her job skills.

loans.use: To purchase braids for her salon

loans.name: Berson

texts.en:
Berson has been in the farming business for the last fifteen years. His mixed farm, which is located in Kisii town in western Kenya, produces tea, bananas and maize which he sells locally. He employs four farmhands.

He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to expand his cereals store. He says that the extra income from this loan will be used to expand his farming. He faces the challenges of a poor road network to the market and insufficient funds for expansion. In the future he would like to buy a piece of land to build some rental houses that will supplement his income.

Berson is 44 years old and married with six children between the ages of 6 months and 16 years. Four of the children are currently attending school.

loans.use: To expand his cereals store

loans.name: Naume

texts.en:
Naume B. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Nansana just outside of Kampala.  She is single and has no children. Naume has a business of selling fruits and vegetables, which she has had for 1 year.  She also has a second business of outside catering. 

To help expand her business, Naume has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase vegetables, Irish and cooking oil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Naume hopes to generate greater profits and taking care of herself.  In the future, Naume hopes to study hair dressing.      Naume is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by knowing how to sing and dance.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and oil for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sugar and charcoal for resale

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun S. is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Sophara Chhom, is 32 years old. They are pictured here together. They live in a village approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1994 and have one young daughter. 

Saroeun sells sewing machines. Her husband is a sewing machine repairman and works along with his wife’s business.  

Saroeun hopes to expand her business by purchasing additional sewing machines for resale, so she is applying for her first loan of $1,000.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a farmer in Kisii town in western Kenya where he has been farming for the last twenty years. His mixed farm produces coffee, maize, beans and milk which are all sold locally. He also depends on his pension pay to meet the needs of his family.

He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will help pay school fees for his children and improve the livelihood of his family. In five years' time, he hopes to have a cooling plant and to improve his milk production.

Stephen is 65 years old and married with five children who are all adults. One of his children is still attending school.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.en:
Cirilo G. is from the village of District 4 in San Manuel, Isabela. He is 46 years old. Cirilo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $230 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cirilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jane Muthoni

texts.en:
Jane Muthoni K. is 40 years old and married to Daniel. They have two children. For the past 11 years, Jane has been operating a restaurant in Githurai 45 from which she earns a monthly profit of 35,000 KES. 

Jane is requesting a loan of 80,000 KES to purchase food stock as well as buy a few tables and chairs to increase her cash flow. This is her first loan with KADET LTD. She plans to save her profit from the loan to purchase a plot of land and build a hotel. In the future, Jane dreams of owning a big hotel with a swimming pool and educating her children.

loans.use: to purchase food stock and tables and chairs

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mrs. Vannak Y. is 30 years old and her husband, Mr. Thearith Chan, is 28 years old. They live in a village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2007 and have one young son.   

Vannak and her husband are farmers and raise pigs. When free, Vannak also sells vegetables, and her husband drives a motor taxi. 

She is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase feed for the pigs and to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

Photo: Mrs. Vannak Y. and her husband

loans.use: To purchase feed for the pigs and to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

loans.name: Sobirahon's Group

texts.en:
Sobirahon A. is the leader of this group.  She is 51 years old and divorced. She has two sons and two daughters. The older son works in construction, the second provides auto repair services, and the daughters study at the university.

In order to earn money, Sobirahon breeds cattle and then resells them at a higher price after fattening.  In this way she earns about $85 per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two bull calves for breeding. 

In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and save money to celebrate her daughter’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two bull calves

loans.name: Savoen

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoen H. (shown in the photo) is 29 years old, and her husband, Mr. Samonn Y, is 30 years old. They live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2005 and have one young daughter.  

Savoen sells groceries at home. Her husband is a goldsmith. She is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to build her own house to live in because she is currently staying with her parents.

loans.use: To build her own house to live in

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel has been practicing mixed farming for the last twenty years in Kisii town in western Kenya. His mixed farm produces maize, millet, cabbages and milk, which are all sold locally. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to meet the basic needs of his family. 

He recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES and has requested this loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He hopes that this dairy cow will improve his milk production and that he will be able to provide his family with enough milk for both domestic consumption and sale. His major challenges have been poor weather conditions and low market prices for his products. He would like to acquire a motorbike in the future that will assist him in the transportation of his products to the market.

Samuel is 58 years old and married with 18 children who are between the ages of 5 and 30. Sixteen of the children are attending school.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ser

texts.en:
Mr. Ser Y. (shown in the photo) is 40 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Thyda Tep, is 31 years old. They live along national road number six about ten kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two daughters. 

Ser is a mechanic. His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,200 to renovate the house where he lives.

loans.use: To renovate the house where he lives.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family and four siblings. He works with his brothers to meet the family’s financiA. target. He has been working in the agriculturA. field for 10 years and bought his own land in 2006. His work consists of cultivating the land to produce vegetables and selling them in the north of Lebanon.

Today, he is asking to borrow $800 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additionA. agriculturA. materials and tools to improve his productivity and; therefore, his sales and profitability.

loans.use: To purchase additional agriculture materials and tools

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Mrs. Simon T. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Nhel, live in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1979 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. 

Simon is a rice farmer. Her husband is a truck driver; he purchases and hauls dirt to sell to villagers for leveling their house foundations. Simon is asking for a loan of $500 to expand her husband's business of purchasing and hauling dirt to sell for leveling house foundations.

loans.use: To expand business of selling dirt for leveling house foundations

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He has been working in agriculture for more than 12 years. In 2000, he purchased his own private land and started cultivating it to produce vegetables. He sells his produce in his town and surrounding areas. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to get essential tools to improve his work and increase his productivity and sales.

loans.use: To buy essential tools

loans.name: Sovan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovan P. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Savuth Chim, live in a Phnom Penh suburb. They were married in 1985 and have two children: one son and one daughter. 

Sovan is a rice farmer. She sells dessert in Oreusey market located in Phnom Penh when she is not at the farm. She is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to build a fence around her house.

loans.use: To build a fence

loans.name: Channy

texts.en:
Mrs. Channy C. (pictured with her husband) is 22 years old. Her husband, Mr. Sineth Chhan, is 27 years old. They live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2008 and have one young son. 

Channy and her husband are vegetable farmers. They grow cabbage and beans on their farmland in the village where they live. Channy is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and two children. He is the only financiA. support for his family. He has 10 years of experience in car maintenance and painting and opened his own garage in 2005. Through the years, he has built a good business reputation.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase extra products for his garage to provide better service for his clients so he can make more profit.

loans.use: To purchase extra products for his garage

loans.name: Mukarramhon's Group

texts.en:
